conclusion: A basketball of mass m is dropped from rest at a height H above the ground. It undergoes an inelastic collision with the ground and rebounds to a maximum height h above the ground.

The magnitude of the air resistance experienced by the basketball during its motion is λ times the magnitude of the gravitational force acting on the basketball (where λ is a constant and 0<λ<(H-h)/(H+h)).
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is the same for each collision with the ground.
The magnitude of the gravitational acceleration is g.
Determine the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground.
Result (ratio of rebound-speed to impact-speed): k ≡ vafter/vbefore = √[(1 + λ) h / ( (1 − λ) H )] (0 < k < 1)

premise: Net downward acceleration during descent from height H: g (1 − λ)
conclusion: Impact speed: vbefore² = 2 g(1 − λ) H

premise: Net downward (retarding) acceleration during rise to height h after the bounce: g (1 + λ)
conclusion: Launch speed just after the bounce: vafter² = 2 g(1 + λ) h

premise: The collision itself is characterised by a constant speed-ratio k, so vafter = k vbefore
conclusion: Substitute the two kinematic results and solve for k: k² [2 g(1 − λ) H] = 2 g(1 + λ) h

premise: Because 0 < λ < (H − h)/(H + h), the square-root argument is less than 1, giving k < 1 as expected for an inelastic bounce.
conclusion: Hence the required ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is k = √[(1 + λ) h / ((1 − λ) H)].
